Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: People do not give it credence that a young girl could leave home and go off in the wintertime to avenge her father's blood, but it did happen.

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: You might say, what business was it of my father's to meddle? My answer is this: he was trying to do that short devil a good turn. He was his brother's keeper. Does that answer your question?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Is that the man?

Speaker: yarnell
Dialogue: Lord lord.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That is my father. 3 Undertaker If you would loik to kiss him it would be all roight.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Tell mama not to sign anything until I return home and see that Papa is buried in his mason's apron.

Speaker: undertaker
Dialogue: Here? Among these people?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: These people?

Speaker: undertaker
Dialogue: I am expecting three more souls. Sullivan, Smith, and His Tongue In The Rain.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How is it that you know in advance?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen beware and train up your children in the way that they should go! You see what has become of me because of drink. I killed a man in a trifling quarrel over a pocketknife.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Can you point out the sheriff?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Him with the mustaches.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Well, I killed the wrong man is the which-of-why I'm here. Had I killed the man I meant to I don't believe I would a been convicted. I see men out there in that crowd is worse than me.

Speaker: indian
Dialogue: I would like to say--

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Oh, Sullivan must'er lost weight in prison! His neck ain't broke!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Hot tamales?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: No, we ain't arrested him. Ain't caught up to him, he lit out for the Territory. I would think he has throwed in with Lucky Ned Pepper, whose gang robbed a mail hack yesterday on the Poteau River.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Why are you not looking for him?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I have no authority in the Indian Nation. Tom Chaney is the business of the U.S. marshals now.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: When will they arrest him?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: Not soon I am afraid. The marshals are not well staffed and, I will tell you frankly, Chaney is at the end of a long list of 7 fugitives and malefactors.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Could I hire a marshal to pursue Tom Chaney?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: You have a lot of experience with bounty hunters?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: My answer is this: That is a silly question. I am here to settle my father's affairs.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: All alone?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am the person for it. Mama was never any good at sums and she can hardly spell cat. I intend to see papa's killer hanged.

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I see. Well. Nothing prevents you from offering a reward, or from so informing a marshal. It would have to be real money, though, to be persuasive. Chaney is across the river in the Choctaw Nation--lawless country. It will not be a daisy-picking expedition. Upwards of three-score US marshals have been slaughtered in the Territory.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I will see to the money. Who's the best marshal?

Speaker: sheriff
Dialogue: I would have to weigh that proposition. I reckon William Waters is the best tracker. He is half Comanche and it is something to see him cut for sign. The meanest one is Rooster Cogburn. He is a pitiless man, double tough and fear don't enter into his thinking. He loves to pull a cork. The best is probably L.T. Quinn, he brings his prisoners in alive. He may let one get by now and again but he believes even the worst of men is entitled to a fair shake. Quinn is a good peace officer and a lay preacher to boot. He will not plant evidence or abuse a prisoner. He is as straight as string. Yes, I will say Quinn is about the best they have. 8

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Where can I find this Rooster?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: The jakes is occupied.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I know it is occupied Mr. Cogburn. As I said, I have business with you.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: I have prior business.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You have been at it for quite some time, Mr. Cogburn.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: There is no clock on my business! To hell with you! To hell with you! How did you stalk me here?!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: The sheriff told me to look in the saloon. In the saloon they referred me here. We must talk.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Women ain't allowed in the saloon!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I was not there as a customer. I am fourteen years old.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: The jakes is occupied. And will be for some time.

Speaker: ross
Dialogue: Yell County Hold at station

Speaker: undertaker
Dialogue: You can sleep in a coffin if you loik.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Not. . . yet.

Speaker: street
Dialogue: 10 Mattie strides along, looking at facades. She stops, looking at the signage on a barnlike building:

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How much are you paying for cotton?

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Nine and a half for low middling and ten for ordinary.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We got most of ours out early and sold it to Woodson Brothers in Little Rock for eleven cents.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Then I suggest you take the balance of it to the Woodson Brothers.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We took the balance to Woodson. We got ten and a half.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Why did you come here to tell me this?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I thought we might shop around up here next year but I guess we are doing all right in Little Rock. I am Mattie Ross, daughter of Frank Ross.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: A tragic thing. May I say your father impressed me with his manly qualities. He was a close trader but he acted the gentleman. 11 Mattie I propose to sell those ponies back to you that my father bought.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: That, I fear, is out of the question. I will see that they are shipped to you at my earliest convenience.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We don't want the ponies now. We don't need them.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Well that hardly concerns me. Your father bought those five ponies and paid for them and there is an end of it. I have the bill of sale.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: And I want three hundred dollars for Papa's saddle horse that was stolen from your stable.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: You will have to take that up with the man who stole the horse.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Tom Chaney stole the horse while it was in your care. You are responsible.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I admire your sand but I believe you will find that I am not liable for such claims.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You were custodian. If you were a bank and were robbed you could not simply tell the depositors to go hang.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I do not entertain hypotheticals, the world as it is is vexing enough. Secondly, your valuation of the horse is high by about two hundred dollars. How old are you? 12 Mattie If anything my price is low. Judy is a fine racing mare. She has won purses of twenty-five dollars; I have seen her jump an eight-rail fence with a heavy rider. I am fourteen.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Hmm. Well, that's all very interesting. The ponies are yours, take them. Your father's horse was stolen by a murderous criminal. I had provided reasonable protection for the creature as per our implicit agreement. My watchman had his teeth knocked out and can take only soup. We must each bear his own misfortunes.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I will take it to law.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: You have no case.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Lawyer J. Noble Daggett of Dardanelle, Arkansas may think otherwise--as might a jury, petitioned by a widow and three small children.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Where is your mother?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: She is at home in Yell County looking after my sister Victoria and my brother Little Frank.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I cannot make an agreement with a minor child. You are not accountable.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Lawyer Dagget will back up any decision I make, you may rest easy on that score. You can confirm any agreement by telegraph.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I will pay two hundred dollars to your father's estate when I have in my hand a letter from your lawyer absolving me of 13 all liability from the beginning of the world to date. The offer is more than liberal and I make it only to avoid the possibility of troublesome litigation.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: A what? All right, now listen very carefully as I will not bargain further. I will take the ponies back and keep the gray horse which is mine and settle for three hundred dollars. Now you must take that or leave it and I do not much care which it is.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Lawyer Daggett would not wish me to consider anything under three hundred twenty-five dollars. But I will settle for three hundred and twenty if I am given the twenty in advance. And here is what I have to say about the saddle--

Speaker: mrs. floyd
Dialogue: Frank Ross's daughter. My poor child. My poor child.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You have my father's traps?

Speaker: mrs. floyd
Dialogue: Oh yes we do. My poor child. Are you gawna be stayin with us or are you hurrying home to your mother?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am staying briefly. I have business with Marshal Rooster Cogburn. I found him in his cups today but I understand he's to be in court tomorrow, testifying. I mean to engage him to hunt down Tom Chaney. 15 Mrs. Floyd Well god bless him for that. The tariff here is seventy-five cents for room and supper. That does not include your daytime eats.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: mrs. floyd
Dialogue: Your father owed for two days, god bless him.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Oh. Well.

Speaker: mrs. floyd
Dialogue: You'll share a room with Grandma Turner. We've had to double up, what with all the people in town come to see the hanging Judge Parker's put on for us.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Yes, I witnessed the hanging myself.

Speaker: mrs. floyd
Dialogue: Was it a good'n?

Speaker: mrs. floyd
Dialogue: This was in the poor man's room. This is everything, there are no light fingers in this house. If you need something for to tote the gun around I will give you an empty flour sack for a nickel.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: The woman was out in the yard dead with blowflies on her face and the old man was inside with his breast blowed open by a scatter-gun and his feet burned. He was still alive but just was. He said them two Wharton boys had done it, rode up drunk--

Speaker: mr. goudy
Dialogue: Objection. Hearsay.

Speaker: mr. barlow
Dialogue: Dying declaration, your honor.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Overruled. Procede, Mr. Cogburn.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Them two Wharton boys--that'd be Odus and C.C.-- throwed down on him, asked him where his money was, when he wouldn't talk lit pine knots and held 'em to his feet. He told 'em in a fruit jar under a gray rock at one corner of the smokehouse. 17 Mr. Barlow And then?

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: . . . Shot or killed?

Speaker: mr. goudy
Dialogue: Let us restrict it to "killed" so that we may have a manageable figure.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Immediate, or--

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Why would I do that?

Speaker: mr. goudy
Dialogue: You did not drag his body over to the fire? Fling his arm in?

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: No sir.

Speaker: mr. goudy
Dialogue: Two witnesses who arrived on the scene will testify to the location of the body. You do not remember moving the body? So it was a bushwack, as he tended his campfire?

Speaker: mr. barlow
Dialogue: Objection.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: I, if that was where the body was I might have moved him. I do not remember.

Speaker: mr. goudy
Dialogue: Why would you move the body, Mr. Cogburn?

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Them hogs rooting around might have moved him. I do not remember.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Son of a goddamn bitch.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Rooster Cogburn?

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: What is it. 24

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I would like to talk with you a minute.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: What is it.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: They tell me you are a man with true grit.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: What do you want, girl? Speak up. It is suppertime.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Let me do that.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: What is your name, girl?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: My name is Mattie Ross. We are located in Yell County. My mother is at home looking after my sister Victoria and my brother Little Frank.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: You had best go home to them. They will need help with the churning.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: There is a fugitive warrant out for Chaney. The government will pay you two dollars for bringing him in plus ten cents a mile for each of you. On top of that I will pay you a fifty- dollar reward.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: What are you?  What've you got there in your poke?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I intend to kill Tom Chaney with it if the law fails to do so.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Well, that piece will do the job--if you can find a high stump to rest it on and a wall to put behind you.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Nobody here knew my father and I am afraid nothing much is going to be done about Chaney except I do it. My brother is a child and my mother is indecisive and hobbled by grief.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: I don't believe you have fifty dollars.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I will shortly. I have a contract with Colonel Stonehill which he will make payment on tomorrow or the next day, once a lawyer countersigns.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: I don't believe fairy tales or sermons or stories about money, baby sister. But thank you for the cigarette.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: Isn't your mother expecting you home, dear? I did not think to see you this evening.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: My business is not yet finished. Mrs. Floyd, have any rooms opened up? Grandma Turner. . . the bed is quite narrow.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: The second-floor back did open up but the gentleman on the porch has just taken it. But don't worry yourself, dear--you are not disturbing Grandma Turner.

Speaker: cowboy
Dialogue: You are sleeping the day away. 27

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am not well.

Speaker: cowboy
Dialogue: You do not look well. My name is LeBoeuf. I have just come from Yell County.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We have no rodeo clowns in Yell County.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: A saucy line will not get you far with me. I saw your mother yesterday morning. She says for you to come right on home.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Hm. What was your business there?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: This is a man I think you know.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Why did you not catch him in Monroe, Louisiana or Pine Bluff, Arkansas? 28 LeBoeuf He is a crafty one.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I thought him slow-witted myself.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That was his act.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It was a good one. Are you some kind of law?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That's right. I am a Texas Ranger.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That may make you a big noise in that state; in Arkansas you should mind that your Texas trappings and title do not make you an object of fun. Why have you been ineffectually pursuing Chaney?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: He shot and killed a state senator named Bibbs down in Waco, Texas. The Bibbs family have put out a reward.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How came Chaney to shoot a state senator?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: My understanding is there was an argument about a dog. Do you know anything about where Chaney has gone?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: He is in the Territory, and I hold out little hope for you earning your bounty.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Why is that?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: My man will beat you to it. I have hired a deputy marshal, 29 the toughest one they have, and he is familiar with the Lucky Ned Pepper gang that they say Chaney has tied up with.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Well, I will throw in with you and your marshal.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: No. Marshal Cogburn and I are fine.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: It'll be to our mutual advantage. Your marshal I presume knows the Territory; I know Chaney. It is at least a two-man job taking him alive.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: When Chaney is taken he is coming back to Fort Smith to hang. I am not having him go to Texas to hang for shooting some senator.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Haw-haw! It is not important where he hangs, is it?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It is to me. Is it to you?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: It means a great deal of money to me. It's been many months' work.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I'm sorry that you are paid piecework not on wages, and that you have been eluded the winter long by a halfwit. Marshal Cogburn and I are fine.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: You give out very little sugar with your pronouncements. While I sat there watching you I gave some thought to stealing a kiss, though you are very young and sick and unattractive to boot, but now I have a mind to give you five or six good licks with my belt.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: Try some Dr. Underwood's. You may feel giddy but do not be alarmed as that is only the medicine working.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: I will charge you ten cents. It probably means a loss for me, but it is hard to figure the exact proportion of the bottle. . .

Speaker: post office
Dialogue: 32 The door bangs open at the cut and Mattie emerges with an envelope.

Speaker: letter
Dialogue: Mattie. I wish you would leave these matters entirely to me, or at the very least do me the courtesy of consulting me before entering such agreements. I am not scolding you, but I am saying your headstrong ways will lead you into a tight corner one day. I trust the enclosed document will let you conclude your business and return to Dardanelle. Your mother is in a panic and begging me to fetch you back home. Yours, J. Noble Dagget.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I was as bad yesterday as you look today. I was forced to share a bed with Grandma Turner.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I am not acquainted with Grandma Turner. If she is a resident of this city it does not surprise me that she carries disease. I was told this malarial place was to be the Chicago of the Southwest. Well, my little friend, it is not the Chicago of the Southwest. I cannot rightly say what it is, but it has ruined my health as it has my finances.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You have not traded poorly.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Certainly not. I am paying you for a horse I do not possess and have bought back a string of useless ponies I cannot sell again.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You are forgetting the gray horse.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: Crowbait.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You are looking at the thing in the wrong light.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I am looking at it in the light of God's eternal truth.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Your illness is putting you "down in the dumps." You will soon find a buyer for the ponies.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: I have a tentative offer of ten dollars per head from the Pfitzer Soap Works of Little Rock.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It would be a shame to destroy such spirited horseflesh.

Speaker: stonehill
Dialogue: So it would. I am confident the deal will fall through.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Look here. I need a pony. I will pay ten dollars for one of them. 34 Stonehill No. That was lot price. No no. Wait a minute. Are we trading again? I just handed you twenty dollars each for those ponies and you now propose to buy one back for ten? Little girl: I will give you ten dollars to refrain from doing any more business here. It would be the most astute deal I have struck in Arkansas.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: This one is beautiful.

Speaker: stableboy
Dialogue: He don't know they's a person up there. You too light.

Speaker: stableboy
Dialogue: He thinks he got a horsefly on him.

Speaker: stableboy
Dialogue: Das a good name.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: What does he like for a treat?

Speaker: stableboy
Dialogue: Ma'am, he is a horse, so he likes apples.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Thank Mr. Stonehill for me.

Speaker: stableboy
Dialogue: No ma'am. . . I ain't s'posed to utter your name.

Speaker: chinese
Dialogue: See. Sleep.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That is fine. I will wake him.

Speaker: chinese
Dialogue: Won't like. 36

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Mr. Cogburn, it is I. Mattie Ross, your employer.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Whuh.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How long til you are ready to go?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Go whar?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Into the Indian Territory. In pursuit of Tom Chaney.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Whah. . .

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Toad her no good!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I said fifty dollars to retrieve Chaney. You did not believe me?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Well, I did not know. You are a hard one to figure.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How long for you to make ready to depart?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Well now wait now, sis. I remember your offer but do not remember agreeing to it. If I'm going up against Ned Pepper I will need a hundred dollars. I can tell you that much. Hundred dollars! I am not pursuing his gang through Arkansas, where there is law, and the criminal is out of his element. They are in the Territory, in their element, where there is no law and the marshal stands alone.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You are trying to take advantage of me.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I am giving you the children's rate. I am not a sharper, I am an old man sleeping in a rope bed in a room behind a Chinese grocery. I should burn this damn thing. It is no good for my back, sister. I have nothing.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You want to be kept in whiskey.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I don't have to buy that, I confiscate it. I am an officer of the court.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I shall not niggle. Can we depart this afternoon?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We?!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You misjudge me if you think I am silly enough to give you fifty dollars and simply watch you ride off.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I am a bonded U.S. marshal!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That weighs but little with me. I will see the thing done.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You never said anything about this. I cannot go up against Ned Pepper and a band of hard men and look after a baby at the same time.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am not a baby.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I will not be stopping at boarding houses with warm beds and plates of hot grub on the table. It will be traveling fast and eating light. What little sleeping is done will take place on the ground.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I have slept out at night. Papa took me and Little Frank coon hunting last summer on the Petit Jean. We were in the woods all night. We sat around a big fire and Yarnell told ghost stories. We had a good time.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Coon hunting! This ain't no coon hunt, it don't come within forty miles of being a coon hunt! 39

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It is the same idea as a coon hunt. You are just trying to make your work sound harder than it is. Here is the money. I aim to get Tom Chaney and if you are not game I will find somebody who is game. All I have heard out of you so far is talk. I know you can drink whiskey and snore and spit and wallow in filth and bemoan your station. The rest has been braggadocio. They told me you had grit and that is why I came to you. I am not paying for talk. I can get all the talk I need and more at the Monarch Boarding House.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Leave the money. Meet me here tomorrow morning at seven o'clock and we will begin our coon hunt.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Dearest Mother. I am about to embark on a great adventure. Or dare I call it a mission, for shall any of us rest easy ere Papa's death is avenged? My investigations in Fort Smith lead me to believe that Tom Chaney can be found and brought to justice, and I have made arrangements to that end. I will return to you once I have seen them properly carried through. . .

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: But do not worry on my account. Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I shall fear no evil. The author of all things watches over me. And I have a fine horse. Kiss Little Frankie for me and pinch Violet's cheek. I am off for the Choctaw Nation.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Where is Marshal Cogburn!

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Went away. . .

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Away! Where?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Here inside is a train ticket for your return home. Use it. By the time you read this I will be across the river in the Indian nation. Pursuit would be futile. I will return with your man Chaney. Leave me to my work. Reuben Cogburn.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Is that Marshal Cogburn?

Speaker: ferryman
Dialogue: That is the man.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Who's he with?

Speaker: ferryman
Dialogue: I do not know.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Take me across.

Speaker: ferryman
Dialogue: So you're the runaway. Marshal told me you'd show up. I'm to present you to the sheriff.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That is a story. Let go my horse. I have business across the river.

Speaker: ferryman
Dialogue: Name ain't Slim.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Run, Little Blackie!

Speaker: ferryman
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Good, Little Blackie!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: That's quite a horse.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: From the money you stole from me?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: That was not stolen. I'm out for your man.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I was to accompany you. If I do not, there is no agreement and my money was stolen.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Marshal, put this child back on the ferry. We have a long road, and time is a-wasting.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: If I go back, it is to the office of the U.S. marshals to report the theft of my money. And futile, Marshal Cogburn-- "Pursuit would be futile"?--is not spelt f-u-d-e-l.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Little sister, it is time for your spanking.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Help me, Marshal!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Now you do as the grown-ups say! Or I will get myself a birch switch and stripe your leg!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Now we will see what tune you sing!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Are you going to let him do this, Marshal?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: No, I don't believe I will. Put your switch away, LeBoeuf. She has got the best of us.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: She has not got the best of me!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Did you not hear me? That will do, I said. 45

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I aim to finish what I started.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: That will be the biggest mistake you ever made, you Texas brush-popper.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Hoorawed by a little girl.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I am not accustomed to so large a fire. In Texas, we will make do with a fire of little more than twigs or buffalo chips to heat the night's ration of beans.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: He has a store.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: A store. That makes him an authority on movements in the Territory?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We have entered a wild place. Anyone coming in, wanting any kind of supply, cannot pick and choose his portal.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That is a piece of foolishness. All the snakes are asleep this time of year.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: They have been known to wake up.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Let me have a rope too.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: A snake would not bother you.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am not going down there again. If you want any more water you can fetch it yourself. 47 Rooster Everyone in my party must do his job.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: You are lucky to be traveling in a place where a spring is so handy. In my country you can ride for days and see no ground water. I have lapped filthy water from a hoofprint and was glad to have it.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: If I ever meet one of you Texas waddies that says he never drank water from a horse track I think I will shake his hand and give him a Daniel Webster cigar.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: You don't believe it?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I believed it the first twenty-five times I heard it. Maybe it is true. Maybe lapping water off the ground is Ranger policy.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: You are getting ready to show your ignorance now, Cogburn. I don't mind a little personal chaffing but I won't hear anything against the Ranger troop from a man like you.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: How long have you boys been mounted on sheep down there?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: My shaggy horse will be galloping when that big American stud of yours is winded and collapsed. Now make another joke about it. You are only trying to put on a show for this girl Mattie with what you must think is a keen tongue.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: This is like women talking.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Yes, that is the way! Make me out foolish in this girl's eyes. 48 Rooster I think she has got you pretty well figured.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Would you two like to hear the story of "The Midnight Caller"? One of you will have to be "The Caller." I will tell you what to say. I will do all the other parts myself.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Good morning, Marshal.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Where is Mr. LeBoeuf?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Down the hill. Performing his necessaries.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Marshal Cogburn, I welcome the chance for a private parley. I gather that you and Mr. LeBoeuf have come to some sort of agreement. As your employer I believe I have a right to know the particulars. 49 Rooster The particulars is that we bring Chaney in to the magistrate in San Saba Texas where they have a considerable reward on offer. Which we split.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I did not want him brought to Texas, to have Texas punishment administered for a Texas crime. That was not our agreement.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: What you want is to have him caught and punished.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I want him to know he is being punished for killing my father.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You can let him know that. You can tell him to his face. You can spit on him and make him eat sand out of the road. I will hold him down. If you want I will flay the flesh off the soles of his feet and find you an Indian pepper to rub into the wound. Isn't that a hundred dollars' value?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It is not. When I have bought and paid for something I will have my way. Why do you think I am paying you if not to have my way?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It is time for you to learn you cannot have your way in every little particular. Other people have their interests.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Little Blackie and I are riding back to the U.S. marshals' office. This is fraud. 50

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: God damn it!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: What's going on?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: This is a business conversation.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Is that what you call it. It sounds to me like you are still being hoorawed by a little girl.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Did you say hooraw!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That was the word.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I will show you hooraw!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: There is no hoorawing in it. My agreement with the Marshal antedates yours. It has the force of law.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: The force of law! This man is a notorious thumper! He rode by the light of the moon with Quantrill and Bloody Bill Anderson!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Those men was patriots, Texas trash!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: They murdered women and children in Lawrence, Kansas.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I have heard that too. It is a damned lie! What army was you in, mister? 51

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I was at Shreveport first with Kirby-Smith--

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: What side was you on?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I was in the army of Northern Virginia, Cogburn, and I don't have to hang my head when I say it!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: If you had served with Captain Quantrill--

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Captain Quantrill indeed!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You had best let this go, LeBoeuf!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Captain of what!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Good, then! There are not sufficient dollars in the state of Texas to make it worth my while to listen to your opinions, day and night. Our agreement is nullified--it's each man for himself!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That suits me!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We'll miss his Sharp's carbine. It's apt to get lively out here.

Speaker: indian youth
Dialogue: Hey.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Call that sport, do ya?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Stay here sister. I will see Bagby.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Has Chaney been here? 53 Rooster No.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: But Coke Hayes was, two days ago. Coke runs with Lucky Ned. He bought supplies, with this.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: This is Papa's gold piece! Tom Chaney, here we come!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It is not the world's only California gold piece.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: They are rare, here.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: They are rare. But if it is Chaney's, it could just as easily mean that Lucky Ned and his gang fell upon him, as that he fell in with them. Chaney could be a corpse. These are a rough lot.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That would be a bitter disappointment, Marshal. What do we do?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We pursue. Ned is unfinished business for the marshals anyhow, and when we have him we will also have Chaney --or we can learn the whereabouts of his body. Bagby doesn't know which way they went, but now we know they come through here, they couldn't be going but one of two ways: north toward the Winding Stair Mountains, or pushing on further west. I suspect north. There is more to rob.

Speaker: youth
Dialogue: Mr. Ferrington will want to know who cut loose his mule.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Tell him it was Mr. James, a bank examiner from Clay County, Missouri.

Speaker: youth
Dialogue: The James boys is said to be slight, Frank and Jesse both.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: One of them has grown fat. The mule will not range far. You boys mend your ways or I will return some dark night and cut off one of your heads--I do not say which--and leave it on the stomach of the other as a warning.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Potter and I served with him at Elkhorn Tavern. Even latterly our activities was by and large martial. We did though, one time, run across a Yankee paymaster and relieve him of four thousand dollars in gold coin. Squealed like it was his own money. Well, since hostilities was officially ended it was technically criminal so Potter rode down to Arkansas and I went to Cairo Illinois with my share, started calling myself Burroughs and opened an eating place called The Green Frog. I married a grass widow but my drinking picked up and my wife did not like the company of my river friends. She decided to go back to her first husband, a clerk in a hardware store. She said, "Goodbye, Reuben, a love for decency does not abide in you." I told her, "Goodbye, Nola, I hope that little nail-selling bastard will make you happy this time." She took my boy with her too. He never did like me anyhow. I guess I did speak awful rough to him but I did not mean nothing by it. You would not want to see a clumsier child than Horace. I bet he broke forty cups. . .

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Is it Chaney?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I would not recognize the soles of his feet.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Step back now.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: God damn it.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Snagged. Well you are going to have to clamber on up with this knife. I am too old and too fat. 56

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It had one billiard table, served ladies and men both but mostly men. I tried to run it myself a while but I couldn't keep good help and I never did learn how to buy meat. I was like a man fighting bees. Finally I give up and solt it and went out to see the country.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You are doing well.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: No! Cut him down!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I might know him.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Why did they hang him so high?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I don't know. Possibly in the belief it would make him more dead.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I do not know this man.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: He knew the hanged man? 59

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: He did not. But it is a dead body, possibly worth something in trade.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: She had taken a notion she wanted me to be a lawyer. Bought a heavy book called Daniels on Negotiable Instruments and set me to reading it. Never could get a grip on it and I was happy enough to set it aside and leave Texas. There ain't but about six trees between there and Canada, and nothing else grows but has stickers on it. I went to--

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I knew it.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Knew what?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We're being followed. I asked the Indian to signal with a shot if there was someone on our trail.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Should we be concerned, Marshal?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: No. It's Mr. LeBoeuf, using us as bird dogs in hopes of cutting in once we've flushed the prey. Our Texas friend has got just enough sense to recognize he can't outtrack me. 60

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Perhaps we could double back over our tracks, and confuse the trail in a clever way.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: No, we will wait right here and offer our friend a warm hello, and ask him where he is going.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You are not LeBoeuf.

Speaker: bear man
Dialogue: My name is Forster. I practice dentistry in the Nation. Also, veterinary arts. And medicine, on those humans that will sit still for it. 61 Rooster  You have your work cut out for you there.

Speaker: bear man
Dialogue: Traded for him with an Indian, who said he came by him honestly. I gave up two dental mirrors and a bottle of expectorant.  Do either of you need medical attention?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: bear man
Dialogue: I have my bearskin. You might want to head to the Original Greaser Bob's. He notched a dugout into a hollow along the Carrillon River. If you ride the river you won't fail to see it. Greaser Bob--Original Greaser Bob--is hunting north of the picket wire and would not begrudge its use.

Speaker: bear man
Dialogue: I have taken his teeth. I will entertain an offer for the rest of him.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Take my jacket. Creep onto the roof. If they are not friendly I will give you a sign to damp the chimney. 62

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Who is out there?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We are looking for shelter.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: No room for you here! Ride on!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Who all is in there?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Ride on!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I am a Federal officer! Who is in there? Speak up and be quick about it.

Speaker: new voice
Dialogue: A Methodist and a son-of-a-bitch!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Is that Emmett Quincy?

Speaker: new voice
Dialogue: I don't know any Emmett Quincy.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Listen here, Emmett Quincy. I know it is you! This is Rooster Cogburn. Columbus Potter and five other marshals is out here with me. We have got a bucket of coal oil. In one minute we will burn you out from both ends! Chuck your arms clear and come out with your hands locked on your head and you will not be harmed. Oncet that coal oil goes down the chimney we are killing everything that comes out the door!

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: There's only two of you!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You go ahead and bet your life on it! How many of you is in there?

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Me and Moon, but he is hit! He can't walk!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Drag him out! Light that lamp! 64 Thinking beat.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Tell them other officers to be careful with their guns! We are coming out!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Down in the snow! Lie still while I cuff you! We is only two, but my man on the roof will shoot you if you get feisty.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: You said it was a man on the roof. I thought it was Potter.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You was always dumb, Quincy, and remain true to form.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: That is our supper and breakfast both. I like a big breakfast.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: Sofky always cooks up bigger than you think.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: We didn't know who was out there weather like this. It might have been some crazy man. Anyone can say he is a marshal.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: My leg hurts.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I'll bet it does. When is the last time you seen your old pard Ned Pepper?

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Ned Pepper? I don't know him. Who is he?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I'm surprised you don't remember him. He is a little fellow, nervous and quick. His lip is all messed up.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: That don't bring anybody to mind.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: There is a new boy that might be running with Ned. He is short himself and he has got a powder mark on his face, a black place. He calls himself Chaney, or Chelmsford sometimes. Carries a Henry rifle.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: That don't bring anybody to mind. Black mark, I would remember that.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You don't remember anything I want to know, do you Quincy? I hope you don't mind. . .

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: I don't know those boys. I always try to help out the law.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: By the time we get back to Fort Smith that leg will be swelled up tight as Dick's hatband. It will be mortified and they will cut it off. Then if you live I will get you two or three years in the Federal house up in Detroit.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: You are trying to get at me.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: They will teach you to read and write up there but the rest of it won't be so good. Them boys can be hard on a gimp.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: You are trying to get at me.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You give me some good information on Ned and I will take you to McAlester's store tomorrow get that ball taken out of your leg. Then I will give you three days to clear the Territory.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: We don't know those boys you are looking for.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It ain't his leg.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Don't go to flapping your mouth, Moon. It is best to let me do the talking.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: I would say if I knew. . . 67 Quincy We are weary trappers.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: The man Chaney with the marked face killed my father. He was a whiskey drinker like you and it led to killing in the end. If you answer the marshal's questions he will help you. I have a good lawyer at home and he will help you too.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: I am puzzled by this.  Why is she here?

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Don't go jawing with these people, Moon. Don't go jawing with that runt.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I don't like you. I hope you go to jail. My lawyer will not help you.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: My leg is giving me fits.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Yes, a young fellow like you don't want to loose his leg. You are too young to be getting about on a willow peg. You love dancing and sport, carrying on.

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Easy now. He is trying to get at you.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I am getting at you with the truth.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: We seen Ned and Haze two days ago. We's supposed-- 68

Speaker: quincy
Dialogue: Don't act the fool! If you blow I will kill you!

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: I am played out. I must have a doctor. We's supposed--

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: God damn it!

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: Oh lord, I am dying!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I can do nothing for you, son. Your pard has killed you and I have done for him.

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: Don't leave me lying here! Don't let the wolves rip me up!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I'll see you are buried right. You tell me about Ned. Where did you see him? 69

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: Two days ago at McAlester's store. They are coming here tonight to get remounts, and sofky. They just robbed the Katy Flyer at Wagoner's Switch if the snow didn't stop 'em.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Should I tell him you was outlawed up?

Speaker: moon
Dialogue: It don't matter, he knows I am on the scout. I will meet him later walking the streets of Glory!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Don't be looking for Quincy.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Hobble our mounts in the corral out back. We don't know when they's coming.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Is he dead?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: He is. I stowed the bodies under the blanket there. Just needs to look right enough to get 'em in the door. 70

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Fingers.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: What do we do now?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We wait. They ride up, what we want is to get them all in the dugout. I will kill the last one to go in and then we will have them in a barrel.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You will shoot him in the back?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It will give them to know our intentions is serious. Then I will call down and see if they will be taken alive. If they won't I will shoot them as they come out. I am hopeful that three of their party being dead will take the starch out of them. 71

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You display great poise.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It is just a turkey shoot. There was one time in New Mexico, when Bo was a strong colt and I myself had less tarnish, we was being pursued by seven men. I turned Bo around and taken the reins in my teeth and rode right at them boys firing them two navy sixes I carry on my saddle. Well I guess they was all married men who loved their families as they scattered and run for home.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That is hard to believe.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: What is?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: One man riding at seven.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: It is true enough. You go for a man hard enough and fast enough and he don't have time to think about how many is with him--he thinks about himself and how he may get clear of the wrath that is about to set down on him.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Why were they pursuing you?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: They was in the nature of a posse.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You were particeps criminis in something other than the case of the Yankee paymaster?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I robbed a high-interest bank. You can't rob a thief, can you? I never robbed a citizen. Never took a man's watch. 72 Mattie It is all stealing.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: That is the position they took in New Mexico.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We have to warn him, Marshal!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Too late.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Oh!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: What do we do, Marshal?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We sit. What does he do?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: He is a fine one for not drawing attention to himself.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Him in the woolly chaps is Lucky Ned.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Well, that's that.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Well that didn't pan out.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: You managed to put a kink in my rope, pardner.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I am theverely injured.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Yes you got drug some.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Altho shshot. By a rifle.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: That is quite possible. The scheme did not develop as I had planned. You have been shot in the shoulder but the ball passed through. It will pain you in the years to come. What happened to your mouth?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I believe I beh mythelf.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Couple of teeth missing and yes, the tongue is bit almost through. Do you want to see if it will knit or should I just yank it free? I know a teamster who bit his tongue off being thrown from a horse. After a time he learned to make himself more or less understood.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Hngnickh.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: What's that now?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Knit.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Very well. It is impossible to bind a tongue wound. The shoulder we will kit out.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I thaw him too. Ith how I came to be here.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Neither of these men are Chaney, Marshal.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I know it. I know them both. The ugly one is Coke Hayes. Him uglier still is Clement Parmalee. Parmalee and his brothers have a silver claim in the Winding Stair Mountains and I will bet you that's where Lucky Ned's gang is waiting. We'll sleep here, follow in the morning.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We promised to bury the poor soul inside. 77

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Ground is too hard. If these men wanted a decent burial they should have got themselves kilt in summer.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Sleep well, Little Blackie. . .

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Azh I understand it, Chaney--or Chelmzhford, azh he called himshelf in Texas--shot the shenator'zh dog. When the shenator remonshtrated Chelmzhford shot him azh well. You could argue that the shooting of the dog wazh merely an inshtansh of malum prohibitum, but the shooting of a shenator izh indubitably an inshtansh of malum in shay.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Malla-men what?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Malum in se. The distinction is between an act that is wrong in itself, and an act that is wrong only according to our laws and mores. It is Latin.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I am struck that LeBoeuf is shot, trampled, and nearly severs his tongue and not only does not cease to talk but spills the banks of English.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I wuzh within three hundred yardzh of Chelmzhford once. The closhesht I have been. With the Sharp'sh carbine, that izh within range. But I wuzh mounted, and had the choish of firing off-hand, or dishmounting to shoot from resht--which would allow Chelmzhford to augment the dishtansh. I fired mounted--and fired wide.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: . . . You could not hit a man at three hundred yards if the gun was resting on Gibraltar. 79

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: The Sharp'sh carbine izh an inshtrument of uncanny power and precizhun.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I have no doubt that the gun is sound.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: That was "Johnny in the Low Ground." There are very few fiddle tunes I have not heard. Once heard they are locked in my mind forever. It is a sadness to me that I have sausage fingers that cannot crowd onto a fretboard--little fat girls at a cotillion. "Soldier's Joy"!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I don't believe he shlept.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Fort Smith is a healthy distance, LeBoeuf, but I would 80 encourage the creature you ride to try to make it in a day. Out here a one-armed man looks like easy prey.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: And a one-eyed man--who can't shshoodt? Why don't you tshurn back, Khoghburn?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I will do fine.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: In conscschiensh you cannot shite our agreement. You are the pershon who shshot me.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Mr. LeBoeuf has a point, Marshal. It is an unfair leg-up in any competition to shoot your opposite number.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: God damn it! I don't accept it as a given that I did shoot LeBoeuf. There was plenty of guns going off.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I heard a rifle and felt the ball. You mishshed your shshodt, Khoghburn, admit it. You are more handicapped without the eye than I without the arm.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Missed my shot! I can hit a gnat's eye at ninety yards!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: The chinaman is running them cheap shells on me again.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I tdhought you were going to shay the shun was in your eyezh. That izh to shay, your eye.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Two at one time!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I will chunk one high. Hold fire.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: There.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: There?! My bullet!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Your bullet? If you hit what you aim at, eckshplain my shoulder!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Gentlemen, shooting cornbread out here on the prairie is getting us no closer to the Ned Pepper gang. 82

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: One more, this will prove it. Hold fire!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Azh I shed, Khoghburn.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Did you not see the piece fly off?!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Find our way back!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Lucky Ned!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Very good, Khoghburn. Now what.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Cogburn does not want me eating out of his store.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: That is silly. You have not eaten the whole day, and it is my store not his.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Let him starve!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That wazh your idea.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: --He does not contribute! He is a millstone, with opinions! He is a man who walks in front of bullets!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Mr. LeBoeuf drew single-handed upon the Lucky Ned Pepper Gang while we fired safely from cover, like a band of sly Injuns!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It is unfair to indict a man when his jaw is swollen and tongue mangled and who is therefore unable to rise to his own defense!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I can thpeak for mythelf. I am hardly obliged to anther the ravingth of a drunkard. It ith beneath me.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Take the girl! I bow out!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: A fine thing to deshide once you have brought her into the middle of the Choctaw Nation. 85 Rooster I bow out! I wash my hands!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Gentlemen, we cannot fall out in this fashion, so close to our goal, with Tom Chaney nearly in hand!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: In hand?! If he is not in a shallow grave, somewhere between here and Fort Smith, he is gone! Long gone! Thanks to Mr. LeBoeuf, we missed our shot! We have barked, and the birds have flown! Gone gone gone! Lucky Ned and his cohort, gone! Your fifty dollars, gone! Gone the whiskey seized in evidence! The trail is cold, if ever there was one! I am a foolish old man who has been drawn into a wild goose chase by a harpy in trousers--and a nincompoop! Well, Mr. LeBoeuf can wander the Choctaw Nation for as long as he likes; perhaps the local Indians will take him in and honor his gibberings by making him Chief! You, sister, may go where you like! I return home! Our engagement is terminated! I bow out!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am going with you.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Oh, that izh not poshible.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Have I held you back? I have a Colt's dragoon revolver which I know how to use, and I would be no more of a burden to you than I was to the marshal. 86

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: That izh not my worry. You have earned your shpurzh, that izh clear enough--you have been a regular "old hand" on the trail. But Cogburn izh right, even if I would not give him the shatishfaction of consheding it. The trail izh cold, and I am conshiderably diminished.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How can you give up now, after the many months you've dedicated to finding Chaney? You have shown great determination. I misjudged you. I picked the wrong man.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I would go on in your company if there were clear way to go. But we would be shtriking out blindly. Chelmshford izh gone--we have chaished him right off the map. There izh nothing for it. I am bound for Texash, and it izh time for you to go home too.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I will not go back. Not without Chaney, dead or alive.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I misjudged you as well. I eckshtend my hand.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Mr. LeBoeuf! Please!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Adiosh!

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Well now I know you. Your name is Mattie. You are little Mattie the bookkeeper. Isn't this something.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Yes, and I know you, Tom Chaney.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I came to fetch water.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I mean what are you doing here in these mountains?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I have not been formally deputized but I am acting as an agent for Marshal Reuben Cogburn and Judge Parker's court.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Well I will not go. How do you like that?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: There is a posse of officers up on the hill who will force you to go.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: That is interesting news. How many is up there?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Right around fifty. They are all well armed and they mean business. What I want you to do now is come on across the creek and walk in front of me up the hill.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I think I will oblige the officers to come after me.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: If you refuse to go I will have to shoot you.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Oh? Then you had better cock your piece.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I know how to do it.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I think not. It is just the other way around. You are going 90 with me. I will--

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I did not think you would do it.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: What do you think now?

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: One of my short ribs is broken. It hurts jiggers every breath I take.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You killed my father when he was trying to help you. I have one of the gold pieces you took from him. Now give me the other.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I regret that shooting. Mr. Ross was decent to me but he ought not to have meddled in my business.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Mattie!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am down here! Chaney is taken into custody!

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I was drinking and I was mad through and through. Nothing has gone right for me.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Everything is against me. Now I am shot by a child.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Stop!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Help me! Down here! Hurry up!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Take them horses you got and move!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Marshal Cogburn and fifty more officers.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Tell me another lie and I will stove your head in!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Just the marshal.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Cogburn! Do you hear me?

Speaker: rooster's voice
Dialogue: The girl is nothing to me! She is a runaway from Arkansas!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: That is very well! Do you advise me to kill her?

Speaker: rooster's voice
Dialogue: Do what you think is best, Ned! She is nothing to me but a lost child!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I will need more than five minutes!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: I will not give you more time.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: There will be a party of marshals in here soon, Ned! Let me have Chaney and the girl and I will mislead them for six hours!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Too thin, Rooster! Too thin! Your five minutes is running! No more talk!

Speaker: rooster's voice
Dialogue: I am leaving but you must give me time!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Up that hill!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Quiet there! 94 The idiot makes a pig-squealing sound in acknowledgment and then falls quiet, loping alongside Mattie and Lucky Ned.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You will not shoot me.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: I will do what I have to do.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Can I have some of that bacon?

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Help yourself. Have some of the coffee.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I do not drink coffee. I am fourteen.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: We do not have buttermilk. And we do not have bread. We are poorly supplied. What are you doing here?

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I will wring your scrawny neck!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Let that go! Farrell, see to his wound. What happened? What are you doing here? 95

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I will tell you what and you will see that I am in the right. Tom Chaney there shot my father to death in Fort Smith and robbed him of two gold pieces and stole his mare. Her name is Judy but I did not see her down at the river. I was informed Rooster Cogburn had grit and I hired him out to find the murderer. A few minutes ago I came upon Chaney watering the horses. He would not be taken in charge and I shot him. If I had killed him I would not be now in this fix. My revolver misfired.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: They will do it. It will embarrass you every time. Most girls like to play pretties, but you like guns do you?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I do not care a thing in the world about guns. If I did I would have one that worked.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I was shot from ambush, Ned. The horses was blowing and making noise. It was that officer that got me.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How can you sit there and tell such a big story?

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: That pit is a hundred feet deep and I will throw you into it and leave you to scream and rot! How do you like that?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: No you won't. This man will not let you have your way. He is your boss and you must do as he tells you.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Five minutes is well up!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: I will give him a little more time.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: How much more?

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Til I think he has had enough.

Speaker: well dressed man
Dialogue: He is gone, Ned! I can see nothing! We had best make a move!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Hold fast a while there, Doctor!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Why doesn't the Doctor do that?

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: He is not a medical doctor. Was that Rooster waylaid us night before last?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: It was Marshal Cogburn and myself.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Yourself, eh? You and Cogburn, quite the posse.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Your friend is gone. You are alone.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: You are too nervous, Doctor. It will be hours before he is back with help.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: They are both dead. I was in the very middle of it. It was a terrible thing to see. Do you need a good lawyer?

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: I need a good judge. What about Coke Hayes--the old fellow shot off his horse?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Dead as well. His depredations have come to an end.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Poor Coke. He rode back for me. Coke Hayes had spine, and could keep his wits in a tight spot. Dead now, but he should have been dead ten times afore now. Your friend Rooster does not collect many prisoners. 98 Mattie He is not my friend. He has abandoned me to a congress of louts.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: You do not varnish your opinions.

Speaker: well dressed man
Dialogue: Are we staying here for chat?

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Do an owl, Harold!

Speaker: idiot
Dialogue: Hoo! Hoo! Hoo!

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Let us cut up the winnings from the Katie Flyer.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: There will be time for that at The Old Place.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I will saddle the grey.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: I have other plans for you.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Must I double-mount with the Doctor?

Speaker: well dressed man
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: No, it will be too chancy with two men up if it comes to a 99 race. You will wait here with the girl. When we reach Ma's house I will send Carroll back with a fresh mount. You will be out by dark and we will wait for you at The Old Place.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I don't like that. Let me ride with you, Ned, just out of here anyway.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: No. We are short a horse. It can't be helped.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Marshals will come swarming.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Hours, if they come here at all. They will guess we are all gone.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am not staying here by myself with Tom Chaney.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: That is the way I will have it.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: He will kill me. You have heard him say it. He has killed my father and now you will let him kill me.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: He will do no such thing. Tom, you know the crossing at Cypress Forks, near the log meetinghouse? When you are mounted you will take the girl there and leave her. Do you understand that, Tom? If any harm comes to this child you do not get paid.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Harold, let me ride up with you.

Speaker: idiot
Dialogue: Baaaaa! Baaaaa!

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Farrel, I will pay you fifty dollars out of my winnings! I am 100 not heavy!

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Ha ha! Do the calf again, Harold!

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Everything is against me.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: You have no reason to whine. If you act as the bandit chief instructed, and no harm comes to me, you will get your winnings at The Old Place.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: They will not wait for me at The Old Place. Lucky Ned has left me, knowing I am sure to be caught when I leave on foot.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: He is sending a mount.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: That was a story. Keep still now. I must think over my position and how I may improve it.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Where is the second California gold piece?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: What have you done with Papa's mare?

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: Keep still, you little busybody. 101 More brooding silence.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Are you thinking about The Old Place? If you will let me go, I will swear to it in an affidavit and once you are brought to justice it may go easier on you.

Speaker: chaney
Dialogue: I tell you I can do better than that. I do not intend to be caught. I need no affidavit.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Sho that ish Chelmthford. Shtrange to be sho closhe at lasht.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: How is it you are here?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I heard the shotsh and went down to the river. . .

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: A plan?

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: He returnzh for Lucky Ned.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: One against four. It is ill advised.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: He would not be dishuaded.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Well, Rooster, will you give us the road?

Speaker: idiot
Dialogue: Moo! Moo!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Hello, Ned. How many men are with the girl?

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Just Chaney. Our agreement is in force: she was in excellent health when last I saw her.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Farrel, I want you and your brother to stand clear. You as well, Doctor. I have no interest in you today.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: What is your intention, Rooster? Do you think one on four is a dogfall?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I mean to kill you in one minute, Ned. Or see you hanged in 104 Fort Smith at Judge Parker's convenience. Which will you have?

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: I call that bold talk for a one-eyed fat man!

Speaker: idiot
Dialogue: Koo koo roo! Blawk!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Fill your hand, you son of a bitch!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Shoot them, Mr. LeBoeuf!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Too far, moving too fasht.

Speaker: lucky ned
Dialogue: Well Rooster, I am shot to pieces. It seems neither of us is to see Judge Parker.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Oh lord.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Some bully shot! Four hundred yards, at least!

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: I am afraid I have--

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Stand up, Tom Chaney!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Mr. LeBoeuf! Are you alive!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Mr. LeBoeuf!

Speaker: rooster's voice
Dialogue: Are you there?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am here!

Speaker: rooster's voice
Dialogue: Can you clamber out?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I cannot!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Awake?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Yes! 110 Rooster appears in the mouth of the pit. He has a rope wrapped round his waist and he starts to descend, half walking, half hopping against the pit wall.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Ahh!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I am bit!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Does Mr. LeBoeuf survive?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: He does--even a blow to the head could silence him for only a few short minutes. Where are you bit?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: My foot is pinned and leg broken.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I have her! Up with us!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I will send help for you as soon as I can. Don't wander off.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We are not leaving him!

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I must get you to a doctor, sis, or you are not going to make it.  The girl is snakebit. We are off.

Speaker: leboeuf
Dialogue: Never doubt the Texash Ranger.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Come on, you!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: We must stop. Little Blackie is played out.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: We have miles yet.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: He is getting away.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Who is getting away?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Chaney.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Hold on, sis.

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: Put your arms around my neck, I will carry.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Where are we?

Speaker: rooster
Dialogue: I have grown old.

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: A quarter of a century is a long time.

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: I had written a letter of thanks to Marshal Cogburn, with an invitation to visit, along with the fifty dollars I owed him. In his reply he promised he would try to call next time he came to Fort Smith with prisoners. Brief though his note was, it was rife with misspellings.

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: Boy.

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: Little Frank had sent me the flier. He had chaffed me through the years over the fact that I had not married, calling the marshal my "secret sweetheart," and he sent a note with the advertisement: "Skill and dash--it's not too late, Mattie!" Little Frank and Victoria have always liked jokes and they are all right in their place. I have never held it against either one of them for leaving me at home to look after Mama, and they know it, for I have told them.

Speaker: standing man
Dialogue: Yes'm, I am Cole Younger. This is Mr. James. It grieves me to tell you that you have missed Rooster. He passed away, what, three days ago, when the show was in Jonesboro Arkansas. Buried him there in the confederate cemetery. Reuben had a complaint what he referred to as "night hoss" 117 and I believe the warm weather was too much for him. We had some lively times. What was the nature of your acquaintance?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: I knew the marshal long ago. We too had lively times. Thank you, Mr. Younger.

Speaker: cogburn
Dialogue: Yell County Hold at station

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: I had the marshal's body removed to Dardanelle. The railroads do not like to carry disinterred bodies in the summertime, but I had my way.

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: . . . It's just like a cranky old maid to pull a stunt like that, burying him in the family plot. They say I love nothing but money and the Presbyterian Church and that is why I never married. It is true that I love my church and my bank. I will tell you a secret. Those same people talk mighty nice when 118 they come in for a crop loan or a mortgage extension. I care nothing for what they say. I would have married a baboon if I had wanted and fetched it its newspaper and slippers every morning but I never had time to fool with it.

Speaker: reuben cogburn
Dialogue: 1835-1908 A Resolute Officer Of Parker's Court

Speaker: voice-over
Dialogue: Anyway, a woman with brains and a frank tongue and one sleeve pinned up and an invalid mother to care for is not widely sought after. I never did see Mr. LeBoeuf again but if he is yet alive I would be pleased to hear from him. I judge he would be in his seventies now and nearer eighty than seventy. I expect some of the starch has gone out of that cowlick. Time just gets away from us.
